content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Congress makes findings related to its responsibility for international commerce, the challenges in overseeing trade policy, the importance of enforcing trade agreements with foreign partners, and concerns about noncompliance by certain countries. The credibility and support for the United States' trade policy depend on the belief that agreements are enforced. The People's Republic of China's accession to the World Trade Organization presents challenges that require Congress to monitor China's compliance with its commitments. Establishment of office. The Congressional Trade Office is established in Congress to provide independent, nonpartisan expertise on international trade, assist in oversight of trade policy, offer direction to the executive branch, maintain institutional memory on trade issues, enhance analytical capability, and advise relevant committees on trade impacts. The Congressional Trade Office is established in Congress to provide independent expertise on international trade, assist in oversight of trade policy, monitor compliance with trade agreements, and advise relevant committees on trade impacts. The Congressional Trade Office is tasked with overseeing trade policy, ensuring foreign countries uphold commitments made in trade agreements with the US, assessing compliance with environmental and labor goals, and conducting annual analyses as required by the Trade Act of 1974. The Congressional Trade Office is responsible for analyzing trade policy, assessing trade barriers, and evaluating trade balances with major trading partners. The Congressional Trade Office analyzes trade policy, trade barriers, and trade balances with major trading partners. It also performs analyses requested by committees on trade-related matters, including proposed legislation, trade agreements, and the impact of trade policy decisions. The Congressional Trade Office participates in dispute settlement deliberations, evaluates outcomes of dispute settlement proceedings, and participates in trade negotiations as observers. Additionally, it performs other functions related to trade policy. The Congressional Trade Office provides Congress with quarterly reports on its activities, consults with congressional committees on trade-related legislation, and performs other trade-related functions as requested by key committee members. Additionally, the Office has the authority to receive and review classified information and participate in classified briefings. The Congressional Trade Office consults with congressional committees on trade-related legislation and performs other trade-related functions. The Director of the Office is appointed by the Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate, without regard to political affiliation. The Director of the Congressional Trade Office is chosen based on expertise and fitness, serving a 5-year term with the possibility of reappointment. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the term, and the Director can be removed by either House of Congress. Compensation is based on the annual rate of pay in effect. The Director of the Congressional Trade Office appoints staff with expertise in international trade, appoints personnel based on fitness, and fixes their compensation. Staff benefits include pay based on the Executive Schedule level III rate. The Office personnel are treated as House of Representatives employees for pay and benefits. The Director can hire experts or consultants for up to 1 year at competitive rates. The Office's relationship to the executive branch is defined by the Director. The Director of the Office can obtain necessary information directly from various government departments and agencies, using their services and facilities if needed. The Director of the Office can coordinate with other congressional agencies to effectively utilize their information, services, and capabilities in carrying out responsibilities. This includes obtaining information from the Government Accountability Office, the Library of Congress, and other offices of Congress, and utilizing their services and facilities as needed. The Office can receive information, data, estimates, statistics, services, and facilities from various congressional agencies, with or without reimbursement. The Comptroller General, the Librarian of Congress, and other offices of Congress are authorized to provide these resources. SEC. 3. PUBLIC ACCESS TO DATA. The Director is required to post all information obtained under the Act on an Office website, make it available for public copying, and provide copies upon request for a fee. Information can only be withheld under specific circumstances. Information can only be withheld under specific circumstances, such as when it pertains to matters necessary to be kept secret in the interests of national defense or the confidential conduct of foreign relations, or when it relates to trade secrets or financial information obtained confidentially. The Director shall provide notice to the public of each instance in which information has been withheld from disclosure, including a description of the information, and shall provide an opportunity for the public to petition the Director to reconsider the determination to withhold disclosure of the information. The Director is required to post all information obtained under the Act on an Office website, make it available for public copying, and provide copies upon request for a fee. Information can only be withheld under specific circumstances, such as matters necessary to be kept secret in the interests of national defense or confidential foreign relations, trade secrets, or financial information obtained confidentially. Committees and Members can request information, data, estimates, and statistics, but can instruct the Director not to make it available for public copying. Authorization of appropriations is granted to the Office for each fiscal year to carry out its duties. Expenses will be covered from the Senate's contingent fund until appropriations are made.
